description: From Middle English cyvylien, from Old French civilien. Equivalent to civil +â€Ž -ian.

entries.meaning: Not related to the military, police or other governmental professions.
examples: The three detainees were actually army defectors wearing civilian clothing.
He worked as a civilian journalist for ten years before being employed by the public broadcaster.

entries.meaning: A person following the pursuits of civil life, especially one who is not an active member of the armed forces.
examples: An army never can be commanded or controlled by civilians.

entries.meaning: (informal) A person who does not belong to a particular group or engage in a particular activity, an outsider.
examples: I have this vision one day that I'll walk amongst you a regular civilian.
Ancient civilians and writers upon government.

entries.meaning: A student of civil law at a university or college.
examples: although he kept his name in the college books, and changed his commoner gown to that of a civilian, yet he had now, I believe, no thoughts of proceeding to any degree; and seldom resided in college any more
